Abstract
Berberine is widely used in traditional Iranian medicine to treat diabetes and inflammatory conditions and also as an anticancer and hepato-protective agent. This study was aimed at developing a method for the preparation of Berberine nanoparticles (Nano-Ber) in order to improve its aqueous-phase solubility and its complex formation with human serum albumin (HSA) and holo-transferrin (HTF) from the viewpoint of interaction behavior. Nano-Ber was prepared with olive oil as the oil phase, Tween 80 as the surfactant, and Span 60 as the co-surfactant. Nano-Ber was obtained with a spherical shape and a mean particle size
of 43.7  3.6 nm, with an optimal oil:surfactant:co-surfactant ratio of 1:2:2, w/w/w. The antioxidant
activity of Nano-Ber in comparison with Berberine was tested using DPPH and it was found that Nano-Ber had a large antioxidant activity. The cytotoxicity effects of Nano-Ber and Berberine on HepG2 were compared by MTT assay and detected in the treated (human liver cancer cell line) HepG2 cells at concentrations up to 0.1 mM. The binding constants of HSA-Nano-Ber and HTF-Nano-Ber complexes formation were (2.93  0.02) × 10 4 M -1 and (9.62  0.03) × 10 3 M -1 respectively. Hydrogen bonds and van
der Waals interactions were the predominant forces in the HSA-Nano-Ber and HTF-Nano-Ber complexes, and the process of Nano-Ber binding HSA and HTF was driven by H 0 = -122.76 kJ.mol -1 , S 0 = -325.49
J.mol -1 K -1 for HSA and H 0 = -125.09 kJ.mol -1 , S 0 = -343.37 J.mol -1 K -1 for HTF. The results of the
simulation demonstrated that the Nano-Ber molecules were stabilized on the surface of final aggregates through both hydrophilic and hydrophobic interactions.
Keywords: Berberine, Nanoemulsion, Olive oil, Antioxidant activity, human serum albumin, holotransferrin, Spectroscopy, Field emission scanning electron microscopy

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Berberine hydrochloride (Berberine) is the primary active component of Rhizoma Coptidis, a major pharmacological component in the south of Iran for treating diabetes and inflammation (James, Fu, Liu, Chen, & You, 2011; Tan, Li, Chen, & Wang, 2011; D. Zhang, Li, Xie, & Ji, 2010). However, the poor water solubility of Berberine impacts its dissolution rate and oral bioavailability, thus limiting its clinical use (Mullauer et al., 2011; S. Wang, Song, & Li, 2000; D. Zhang et al., 2010). It is sparingly soluble in methanol, slightly soluble in ethanol and even less soluble in water. However, the salt forms are relatively soluble and contribute to tissue coloring (Kim et al., 2005). Oral administration of Berberine (Scheme 1) has exhibited low bioavailability and poor stability mainly due to its hydrophobic properties resulting from the chemical structure, which contains two methoxy groups and a quaternary ammonium cation.
Berberine appears to be a hydrophilic compound and has a log P-value of -1.5, making it a class-III drug in the biopharmaceutical classification system (Battu et al., 2010; Madara, 1989). Drugs included in this class are lipophobic and have reduced membrane permeability, and the absorption of the drugs is mostly limited to the para-cellular pathway. This restricts intestinal absorption and leads to low bioavailability. Therefore, it is of great importance to develop a novel drug delivery system to improve the solubility and bioavailability of Berberine (Shen, Li, Huan, & Shen, 2010; Tan et al., 2011).
In recent years, many approaches have indicated that the water solubility and bioavailability of Berberine become significantly improved when reducing its particle size down to the nano-scale (Basniwal, Buttar, Jain, & Jain, 2011). A nano-emulsion is a thermodynamically stable system in which transparent dispersions of oil and water with droplet sizes smaller than 100 nm are stabilized by an interfacial film of surfactant molecules. In recent years, nano-emulsions have become a promising approach for the delivery of poorly water-soluble drugs to improve oral bioavailability as well as to modify drug release characteristics (Aboalnaja, Yaghmoor, Kumosani, & McClements, 2016; Akhtar et al., 2016; Khani, Keyhanfar, & Amani, 2016). Thanks to the oil-in-water (O/W) emulsion technique, lipophilic bioactive components can be produced and solubilized within the oil phase and then be homogenized in an aqueous phase that contains a water-soluble emulsifier. The O/W emulsion method is physico-chemically sensitive
since the size of the nano-particles (droplets 100 nm) is extremely dependent on the chemical
composition that is used, as well as the physical condition (homogenization). The nano-emulsions that are

produced by the O/W emulsion method have displayed higher stability, while they are often found to have different physico-chemical, biological and medicinal properties in comparison with conventional emulsions (Sonneville-Aubrun, Simonnet, & L'alloret, 2004).
The interaction behavior between drugs and plasma proteins is of crucial importance in order to understand the pharmacodynamics and pharmacokinetics of drug-drug binding and the influence on the distribution, excretion, metabolism, and interaction with the target tissues. Drugs are mainly transported by human serum albumin (HSA) and human holo-transferrin (HTF). HSA and HTF have many essential physiological and pharmacological functions and have been the most extensively studied of all proteins(He & Carter, 1992). The choice was made to investigate Nano-Ber because of its physiological and pharmacological effects mentioned above. It is widely accepted in the pharmaceutical industry that the overall distribution, metabolism, and efficacy of many drugs can be altered based on their affinity with serum proteins. Besides, many promising new drugs are rendered ineffective because of their unusually high affinity for this abundant protein (Carter & Ho, 1994). An understanding of the chemistry of the various classes of pharmaceutical interactions with HSA and HTF can suggest new approaches to drug therapy and design. Despite much information on the biological activity of Nano-Ber, the interaction of HSA and HTF with Nano-Ber has not yet undergone a detailed investigation.
The objective of this study was to develop a nanoemulsion delivery system of Nano-Ber by utilizing olive oil as a suitable oil phase due to its unique properties and health benefits which include being used as a skincare product, a lubricant for kitchen utensils and an agent providing acidic sensory properties to aroma and flavor (Bendini et al., 2007). Furthermore, the interaction between Nano-Ber with HSA or HTF, the two critical proteins in drug delivery, has been studied.

sections.heading: 2.2. Preparation of Nano-Berberine (Nano-Ber)
sections.text:
During the preparation of Nano-Ber via the oil-in-water (O/W) emulsion method, the oil phase (olive oil), surfactant (Tween 80) and co-surfactant (Span 60) were mixed (at a ratio of 1:2:2 w/w/w) during shaking for 30 min to form the oily phase. 320 mg of the initial Berberine was added into the oil phase, and the
mixture was continuously stirred at (40 C, 3000 rpm) for 24 h to achieve dissolution equilibrium.
Subsequently, after standing for 24 h and reaching equilibrium at 25 C, each vial was centrifuged at 4000
rpm for 10 min using a centrifuge from Hettich, Germany. Un-dissolved Berberine was removed by a
membrane filter (0.45 m). Then, the mixture was placed in a sonicator bath (Sonorex Digitec, Model:
Andelin 35 kHz, Germany) for a period of 1h to obtain a transparent yellow homogeneous oily solution.
Then, 100 l of the mixture was dispersed in 50 ml double distilled water and the droplet size was
determined after dilution. Additionally, oil and the surfactant/co-surfactant mixture were mixed thoroughly in different volume ratios (1:1:1, 2:1:1, 1:2:1 and 2:1:2) to optimize the size of the prepared Nano-Ber.

sections.heading: 2.3. Nano-Ber characterization
sections.text:
Measurements to determine the particle size distribution and zeta potential of Nano-Ber were conducted on a zeta-sizer Nano ZS model (Malvern Instrument, UK). Dynamic light scattering was used for the particle size distribution which was obtained by measuring the intensity fluctuations over time of a laser beam scattered by the sample at an angle of 173°. The zeta potential measurements were performed based on laser Doppler anemometry, using the same machine. For the zeta potential measurements, the sample was loaded into pre-rinsed folded capillary cells and a minimum of three measurements were carried out per sample. Each measurement had an average of 13 runs. All of the measurements were applied at room temperature. The surface morphology of Nano-Ber (freeze-dried powder) was observed via a MIRA model of field emission scanning electron microscopy (FESEM, Tescan Mira 3, Czech Republic) at an accelerating voltage of 20 kV. Drops of the samples were dried on a metallic substrate and were coated with gold in an ion sputter under vacuum for 180 s before the observation. Ac ce

Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) experiments were performed as follows. Drops of the (freshly) prepared Nano-Ber emulsion (1 mg/ml) were dripped onto the carbon-coated copper grids and kept for 1 min, while the excess solution was removed by filter paper. Then, one drop of uranyl acetate solution (2% w/v), as the negatively stained standard, was applied to stain the sample for about 1 min as reported elsewhere (Doktycz et al., 2003). Following this, the sample was dried at ambient temperature overnight before capturing the TEM images. A Nano-Ber emulsion suspended in distilled water was prepared for
AFM imaging by placing a 10 l aliquot of the sample on gelatin-coated mica, spreading the sample with a
micropipette tip and allowing the sample to air dry (Y. Zhang, Cui, Gao, & Jiang, 2013). After drying, the samples were imaged in air in either contact mode or MacMode with a Picoplus AFM (Molecular Imaging, Tempe, AZ, USA) under environmental control (12% relative humidity) using silicon nitride cantilevers (MLCT-AUHW, Veeco, Santa Barbara, CA, USA) with a manufacturer's suggested spring constant of 0.1 Nm -1 and a tip radius of curvature of 20 nm. All images were acquired at 1.0 scan lines s -1
with 512 points/scan line. The setpoint and servo gain (proportional and integral) were adjusted for optimal image quality. Most of the AFM images presented were either deflection or amplitude images allowing for a complete picture of the sample morphology. All of the quantitative data were taken from topographic images of sample surfaces where scan lines were used to identify distances and heights.
The differential scanning calorimetry (DSC) analysis of Berberine, Tween 80, Span 60, olive oil, physical mixture, and Nano-Ber were carried out using a METTLER TOLEDO DSC, Model 822 (Switzerland). Samples of approximately 2-3 mg were weighed and hermetically sealed in aluminum pans. The samples
were heated from 40 C to 280 C at a heating rate of 10 C/min under a nitrogen purge at a flow rate of
20 ml/min. An empty aluminum pan was used as the reference.

sections.heading: 2.4. Antioxidant activity and Cytotoxicity assay
sections.text:
The radical scavenging activity of the nanoparticles was examined by the reduction of DPPH via a simple spectrophotometric titration, as reported previously (Brand-Williams, Cuvelier, & Berset, 1995; Joung et al., 2016). A methanolic solution of DPPH radicals was freshly prepared at a concentration of 0.1 mM. In the absence of antioxidant compounds the radical was stable for more than 3h of a conventional kinetic
assay. To evaluate the relative radical scavenging activities, 100 l of each sample was mixed with 500 l

methanolic solution of DPPH radicals (0.1 mM) and the mixtures were kept in the dark under vigorous shaking for 30 min. The radical scavenging activities were evaluated by the corresponding decrease in absorbance of the blank containing methanol without DPPH at 515 nm using a UV-visible spectrophotometer (Jasco, V-630, Japan). The antiradical action toward the DPPH radical was estimated from the difference in absorbance with or without the sample (control), and the percent of inhibition was calculated from the following equation:
%Inhibition = [(absorbance of control – absorbance of test sample) / absorbance of control] × 100
When the standard deviation values were higher than 10%, the analyses were repeated to confirm the values. Three samples of each item were analyzed, and the main values as well as the standard deviation were given.
Human liver cells, HepG2, were obtained from Pasteur Institute, Tehran, Iran. The cells were grown in
DMEM with 10% Fetal Bovine Serum (FBS), penicillin/streptomycin (100 units/ml) at 37 C and 5%
CO2. All the treatments were conducted at 37 C and a cell density allowing exponential growth. The
cytotoxicity of Nano-Ber was determined by a 3-(4, 5-dimethyl thiazol-2-y1)-2, 5-diphenyltetrazolium bromide (MTT) assay (Pal et al., 2019). Briefly, around 1 × 10 4 cells per well of 96-well plates were
exposed to Nano-Ber for 24h of incubation at 37 C and 5% CO2. Following this, the cells were incubated
again with 10 l MTT solution (stock 1 mg/ml) for 4h at 37 C and 5% CO2 following a wash with 1 ×
phosphate-buffered saline (PBS) and the resulting crystals were dissolved in MTT solubilization buffer to measure the absorbance at 570 nm by using a microplate reader. The data were compared with those from the control samples.

sections.heading: 2.5. Spectroscopic measurements
sections.text:
The fluorescence experiments were carried out on a spectrofluorimeter (Hitachi F-2500) equipped with a 150-W xenon lamp source and 1.0-cm quartz cell. Slit widths for both monochromators were set at 10 nm. A 2.0-ml solution containing an appropriate concentration of plasma proteins was titrated manually by the successive addition of Nano-Ber (final concentration was 5 × 10 -2 mM) with syringes. The excitation
wavelength for Trp was 280 nm, and the emission wavelength was 300-500 nm. To decrease the inner

filter effect, the fluorescence intensities used in the present study were corrected for the absorption of the excitation light and re-absorption of emitted light using the formula:
Fcor = Fobs e (Aex + Aem)/2
where Fcor and Fobs are the corrected fluorescence intensity and observed fluorescence intensity,
respectively, and Aex and Aem are the absorptions of the system at the excitation wavelength and the emission wavelength, respectively(Chanphai, Ouellette, Bérubé, & Tajmir-Riahi, 2018).
Circular dichroism spectra were recorded in the range from 200 to 300 nm at an interval of 0.2 nm with a Jasco J-815 spectropolarimeter equipped with a temperature control unit. The instrument was run with a Jasco Spectra Manager TM software. The scanning rate, bandwidth, and response were set at 50 nm min -1 ,
1 nm and 2 s, respectively. The instrument was calibrated using d-10-camphorsulphonic acid. A quartz cuvette with a path length of 1 mm was used. Each spectrum was the mean of five successive scans with a protein concentration constant of 1 × 10 -3 mM for both proteins. In order to explore changes in secondary
structure, far-UV CD spectra were obtained over a wavelength range of 190-240 nm in the absence and presence of different concentrations of Nano-Ber under identical conditions for separate HSA and HTF solutions. In all titration experiments, the dilution factor of the ligand titration was corrected. The absorption spectra were measured on a Jasco V-630 UV-visible spectrophotometer. A quartz cell of 1.00 cm was used for the measurements. The optical system was based on a split-beam with a grating bandwidth of 5 nm. The light source was a Xenon lamp.

sections.heading: 2.6. System design
sections.text:
The molecular dynamic (MD) simulation system consisted of olive oil, span 60/tween 80 as surfactants and Berberine. Experimental studies showed that the optimum ratio of oil:surfactant for dissolving Berberine was 2.5:1. Theoretically, crude olive oil contains 13.8% saturated fatty acids, 73% monounsaturated fatty acids, 9.7% ω-6 and 0.7% ω-3 fatty acids (T. H. Borges et al., 2019; QuinteroFlorez, Sinausia Nieva, Sanchez-Ortiz, Beltran, & Perona, 2015). The major saturated and polyunsaturated fatty acids are palmitic acid (a small percentage of stearic acid) and linoleic acid. Furthermore, olive oil is rich in monounsaturated oleic acid. To simulate the experimental nanoemulsion system the concentration

sections.heading: 2.7. MD simulation
sections.text:
The primary structures of the molecules were drawn in Chem Draw™ and after initial energy minimization; the molecules were introduced in the MOE 2015.1 software for final optimization. The atom amber force field was applied on each molecule while all polar and non-polar hydrogens had been added. Because there is no defined force field for the small molecules, the topology and coordinate files of the components were prepared using the SwissParam online server.
MD simulations were performed in GROMACS 2019 (Thays Helena Borges et al., 2019) based on the Charmm (Vanommeslaeghe & MacKerell, 2012) all-atom forcefield. The size of the simulation box was set to 15×15×15 nm 3 and a TIP3P water model (Harrach & Drossel, 2014) was appended to fill the box. Energy minimization was applied by the steepest descent algorithm. Afterward, the system was heated by an NVT ensemble thermostat to relax at 300 K for 100 ps. For the second equilibration step, an NPT ensemble thermostat was applied to maintain 1-bar pressure during the simulation time.
Finally, MD simulations were performed for a 100-ns simulation time by the Leap-Frog integrator. During all simulation steps, the output files were written every 2 fs and constraints were applied on all bonds by the LINCS algorithm (Hess, Bekker, Berendsen, & Fraaije, 1997). Short range electrostatic and Van der Waals cutoffs were set to 1 nm and the Particle–Mesh–Ewald (PME) method (Essmann et al., 1995) was appended for long range electrostatic interactions. The temperature and pressure of the system remained constant during the whole simulation time by Berendsen and Parrinello–Rahman coupling algorithms (Berendsen, van Postma, van Gunsteren, DiNola, & Haak, 1984; Parrinello & Rahman, 1981).
To analyze the trajectories, Periodic boundaries were removed, and the number of clusters was counted throughout the simulation time. The neighboring molecules at a distance of less than 3.5 Å were considered as one cluster. To picture the mechanism of the aggregation, different snapshots were recorded and visualized by MOE 2015.1.

sections.heading: 3.1. Formation and stability of Nano-Ber
sections.text: The formation of Nano-Ber can be determined by the maximum absorption peak that can be measured through UV-visible spectrophotometry in the wavelength range of 200-500 nm. The prepared Nano-Ber revealed a maximum absorption peak at 340 nm (Fig. 1). The characteristic of the maximum absorption peak (340 nm) was utilized for the stability evaluation of prepared Nano-Ber (pH = 6.90). Fig. 1 shows a decrease that was determined after two months and the further decline that was revealed over a longer period (5 months), which points out the stability of the Nano-Ber emulsion system.

sections.heading: 3.2. Differential scanning calorimetry (DSC) analysis
sections.text:
DSC conducted the thermal behavior analysis of Nano-Ber and the other substances. In the thermograms shown in Fig. 2, the temperature is plotted on the x-axis and the heat flow (increasing endotherm) on the yaxis. Fig. 2 shows the DSC thermograms of Berberine, olive oil, Tween 80, Span 60, Nano-Ber, and their physical mixture. As can be seen from the figure, a sharp endothermic peak of Berberine appeared at
approximately 190 C, and was assigned to its melting (Y. Zhang et al., 2013). The strong and wide
endothermic peak in the range between 90 and 120 C could be attributed to the dehydration of Berberine.
The disappearance of the Berberine peak in the DSC thermograph of Nano-Ber could be associated with the change of Berberine from a crystalline to an amorphous phase caused by the interactions between Berberine and the surfactants (Tween 80 and Span 60), while the solubility rate of Berberine was increased. The prepared Nano-Ber had almost the same melting point as that of the unprocessed Berberine, but the endothermic melting peak was less intense, with an enthalpy of fusion lower than the unprocessed Berberine. The reduction in enthalpy values was an indication of crystallinity due to the decrease in particle size (Kakran et al., 2010; Patel & Patel, 2007; Shid, Dhole, Kulkarni, & Shid, 2014)

sections.heading: 3.3. Particle size and zeta potential measurements
sections.text: The polydispersity index can give an idea of the mono-dispersity of Nano-Ber. The mean particle size and polydispersity index (PDI) were measured after the preparation of the Nano-Ber. The mean particle size with PDI 0.425 ± 0.101 was 43.7 ± 3.6 nm (see Fig. 3A). Values below 0.5 indicate a high degree of homogeneity in particle size and vice versa. Besides, the zeta potential analysis can predict the stability of a nano-emulsion by determining the surface charges, especially in nano-materials (Rai, Pandit, Gaikwad, Yadav, & Gade, 2015). The zeta potential of Nano-Ber was -57.4 mV ± 0.62 (see Fig. 3B), which can be interpreted as the prepared nano-emulsion having an anionic nature (Evans, Romanick, & Ferguson, 2017). This zeta potential value can be associated with Tween 80 as a nonionic surfactant and Span 60 as a co-surfactant that has covered the surface of droplets (Mun, Decker, & McClements, 2005).

sections.heading: 3.4. Morphology of Nano-Ber
sections.text:
High magnification transmission electron microscopy (TEM), field emission scanning electron microscopy (FESEM), and atomic force microscopy (AFM) were utilized to determine the size and morphology of the prepared Nano-Ber. Fig. 4A shows a TEM image of Nano-Ber revealing spherical shapes with a uniform size distribution. FESEM of the prepared Nano-Ber was also carried out at different magnifications (Fig. 4B) and showed homogeneous and spherical shapes that are well dispersed in the emulsion. AFM analysis displayed that the prepared Nano-Ber was spherical in shape and had a uniform size distribution (see Fig. 4C). The high surface area due to particle size reduction enhanced the solubility, dissolution rate, and bioavailability of the Nano-Ber.

sections.heading: 3.5. Antioxidant properties and cytotoxicity effects
sections.text:
The absorbance of the ethanolic DPPH solution at 517 nm became gradually reduced while the free radicals were scavenged, and the color of the solution changed from purple to yellow (Xie, Huang, Xu, & Jin, 2008). The method is based on the reduction of the absorbance of ethanolic DPPH solution at 517 nm in the presence of a proton-donating substance, due to the formation of the diamagnetic molecule by accepting an electron or hydrogen radical (Cheng, Wang, & Xu, 2006). Therefore, to prove this, DPPH assay was used to determine the free radical scavenging activity (RSA) of Berberine and another used substance.
Fig. 5 demonstrates the antioxidant activity of the prepared Nano-Ber, Berberine, Tween 80, Span 60, Olive oil, and the Tween 80-Span 60-Olive oil (TSO) mixture. The results revealed that the values of
RSA% for the above compounds were 91  0.4, 79  0.6, 17  0.5, 18  0.5, 19.1  1.2 and 32  0.6
respectively. As a result, the prepared Nano-Ber presented a higher antioxidant activity ( 14%) in
comparison with pure Berberine, which may be related to the reduction in size and the exposure of a relatively high number of OH groups from the Berberine molecules reducing the free radical (Rao & Khanum, 2016). In the present study, the prepared Nano-Ber can be incorporated in food products to promote their antioxidant properties and health beneficial therapeutic activity.

An MTT assay was conducted to assess the concentration-dependent cytotoxic effects of the Nano-Ber and Berberine solutions (Fig. 6). HepG2 was chosen as a cell line to investigate the cytotoxicity of Nano-Ber. Fig. 6 illustrates the viability percentage of the cell lines in the applied concentrations of prepared NanoBer. As can be seen, the Berberine solution showed non-significant cytotoxicity at concentrations between 0.05 and 4 mM, while Nano-Ber showed non-significant cytotoxicity at concentrations between 0.05 and 0.1 m. These results indicate the possibility of Nano-Ber usage in different biomedical applications such as gene and drug delivery.

sections.heading: 3.6. Fluorescence quenching of HSA and HTF by Nano-Ber
sections.text:
The fluorescence quenching spectra of HSA and HTF by Nano-Ber are presented in Fig. 7 (A, B). HSA
and HTF can emit fluorescence at 343 nm and 331 nm, when ex is 280 nm, while Nano-Ber could not emit fluorescence within the range of the experimental wavelength (data not shown). As can be seen from Fig. 7(A, B), the fluorescence intensity of HSA and HTF regularly decreased with the enhancement of Nano-Ber. The fluorescence quenching of HSA and HTF revealed that Nano-Ber bound to HSA and HTF.
To interpret the data from fluorescence quenching studies, it is important to understand what kind of interaction that took place between HSA or HTF with Nano-Ber. If it is assumed that the fluorescence quenching of HSA or HTF induced by Nano-Ber is a dynamic quenching process, fluorescence quenching is described by the Stern-Volmer equation:
F0/F = 1+ kq 0 [Q] = 1+ Ksv [Q] (1)
Here, F and F0 are the fluorescence intensity with and without Nano-Ber, respectively, kq is the quenching
rate constant of the biomolecule, Ksv is the Stern-Volmer quenching constant, 0 is the average lifetime of the biomolecule without quenchers, and [Q] is the concentration of quencher. Obviously
Ksv = kq0 (2)

Because the fluorescence lifetime of the biopolymer is 10 -8 s -1 , (Mokaberi et al., 2019), Ksv is the slope of
the linear regression of Fig. 8 (A, B). Based on equation 2, the quenching constant kq can be obtained and is listed in Table 2, together with the correlation coefficients. However, the maximum scattering collision quenching constant kq of various quenchers with the biopolymer is 2× 10 10 L mol -1 s -1 (Kamshad,
Jahanshah Talab, Beigoli, Sharifirad, & Chamani, 2019). The fluorescence data obtained at room temperature (298 K) was further examined using the modified Stern-Volmer equation [46]:
F0 / (F0-F) = 1/f + 1/Kafa[Q] (3)
where Ka is the effective quenching constant for the available fluorophore.
There are mainly four modes of the binding of small molecules to proteins: H-bonds, van der Waals forces, and electrostatic and hydrophobic interactions. The thermodynamic parameters, enthalpy (H 0 ), and entropy (S 0 ) of the binding interaction are important for confirming binding modes. Therefore, the
temperature dependence of the binding constants was studied. Experiments were conducted at 298, 303, and 308 K since HSA and HTF do not undergo any gross structural changes in this temperature range (Chamani, Vahedian-Movahed, & Saberi, 2011). Because the enthalpy changes (H 0 ) do not vary significantly over the temperature range, entropy changes (S 0 ) can be distinguished by the van't Hoff
equation:
lnKa = -H 0 /RT + S 0 /R (4)
where associative binding constants (Ka) are the modified Stern-Volmer quenching constants at the corresponding temperature, and R is gas constant.
The values of H 0 and S 0 were obtained from the linear van’t Hoff plot. The value of G 0 was calculated
from the equation:
G 0 = H 0 - TS 0 (5)

From Table 2, it can be seen that H 0 and S 0 for the binding interaction between HSA and HTF with Nano-Ber were calculated as -122.76 kJ.mol -1 , -325.49 Jmol -1 K -1 and -125.09 kJ.mol -1 , -343.37 Jmol -1 K -1
respectively which indicated that the binding process was an exothermic reaction. The negative values of G 0 pointed to the interaction process being spontaneous. In the present study, the negative values of H 0 and S 0 for HSA-Nano-Ber and HTF-Nano-Ber complexes led to the conclusion that the acting forces
were mainly hydrogen bonds and van der Waals forces.

sections.heading: 3.6. Energy transfer between Nano-Ber and HSA or HTF
sections.text:

sections.heading: 3.7. Circular dichroism (CD) measurements
sections.text:
CD spectra of HSA and HTF exhibit two negative bands at 208 nm and 221 nm that are characteristic of an alpha-helix in the advanced structure of the protein (Zolfagharzadeh, Pirouzi, Asoodeh, Saberi, & Chamani, 2014). The spectra will change when altering the content of alpha-helices. Fig. 10 (A, B) shows the CD spectra of HSA and HTF in the absence and presence of Nano-Ber. As can be seen from Fig. 10 (A, B), the addition of Nano-Ber to HSA and HTF enhances the ellipticity, indicating that the binding of Nano-Ber to HSA and HTF induces an enhancement in the alpha-helical content of both proteins. Meanwhile, the CD spectra of HSA and HTF without and with Nano-Ber are similar in shape, indicating that the structures of HSA and HTF are also predominately alpha-helical after the binding of Nano-Ber (Zaidi & Khan, 2019). From the above results, it is apparent that the binding of Nano-Ber to HSA or HTF caused conformational changes of both proteins with an enhancement of the alpha-helical stability. Table 3 indicates the secondary structural contents of HSA and HTF in the absence and presence of Nano-Ber. As can be seen from Table 3, the alpha-helix and beta-sheet contents of both proteins became raised with the enhancement of Nano-Ber concentration. The increase in secondary structure elements of HSA and HTF in the presence of Nano-Ber determined that electrostatic forces played an important role in the interaction behavior of the HSA-Nano-Ber and HTF-Nano-Ber complexes. sections.heading: 3.8. Molecular dynamics simulations
sections.text:
The formation of nanoemulsion droplets is a spontaneous process. During the first nanoseconds of simulation, the hydrophobic and hydrophilic interactions rearrange the small molecules to form aggregates. For this, the temperature and concentration of the nanoemulsion components are very important for creating small-sized droplets of a specific shape (Faujan, Abedi Karjiban, Kashaban, Basri, & Basri, 2015). Fig. 11 indicates that in the first 10 ns of the simulation, a self-assembly occurred. At the beginning of the simulation, the molecules spread randomly; however, gradually the aggregates formed and became stabilized until the end of the 100 ns simulation. To get a quantified view of the formation of the nano-droplets, the number of clusters was counted during the time of the simulation in Fig. 12. In this plot, it is clear that the number of clusters decreased slowly and became constant after approx. 20 ns (six to seven clusters) until the end of the simulation. The establishment of the nano-aggregates was the result of electrostatic interactions between small molecules (Faujan et al., 2015).
Another factor for the evaluation of the aggregate stability is the radius of gyration (Rg). The radius of gyration describes the compactness of the droplets during the time of the simulation. It is important for the droplets to have stable Rg during the last nanoseconds of the modeling. In this study, the Rg of the biggest cluster which comprised 2 aggregates was calculated throughout the last 20 nanoseconds of the simulation and was found to be 12.85±0.04 nm (Abdul Rahman et al., 2009).
For a closer look at the clusters’ spherical shape, the ratio of the average principal moments of inertia was estimated for the biggest cluster (MacKerell, 1995; Tieleman, van der Spoel, & Berendsen, 2000). Fig. 13 demonstrates the biggest cluster’s moments of inertia in three axes (x, y and z). The results of the averaged moments of inertia in the last 5 ns of simulation reached a ratio of 1:1.5:2.1. Although proportions of the values were very close, the shape was a prolate spheroid. The calculation of the eccentricity (e) of the

aggregates reconfirmed the non-spherical structure of the assemblies which is reported in Table 4. For the best spherical shape, eccentricity must be close to zero.
The solvent accessibility surface areas (SASA) of the nano particles were measured in Fig. 14. The SASA of the hydrophobic interaction decreased in the first 15 ns of the simulation. This pattern was also seen for the total SASA. However, the area of the hydrophilic interactions remained constant during the course of the simulation. Although both hydrophilic and hydrophobic interactions are necessary for the formation of aggregates, the reduction of the hydrophobic part is the crucial step in the development of stable nanoparticles (Faujan et al., 2015). In this study, a reduction of the hydrophobic SASA means that the hydrophobic groups tried to get buried in the interior part of the nano-droplets to maximize the hydrophilic interactions. The averaged total SASA interaction was 443.7±5 nm 2 , while the averaged SASA values for the hydrophobic and hydrophilic interactions were respectively 266.2±4 and 177.5±2 nm 2 during the last 5 ns of the simulation.
To get deep insight into the mechanism of dissolving Berberine hydrochloride, the interaction of Berberine with oil/surfactant molecules was studied by Radial Distribution Function (RDF). RDF is a factor for estimating the nano-droplet’s structures. In general, it reports the probability (g(r)) of finding two particles at specified distances (Tieleman et al., 2000). Fig. 15 displays a plot of the ARDF factor between Berberine and oil/surfactant groups against the distance (r) out of the MD trajectories. At very close distances (r<0.2 nm), the repulsive interaction forces showed that the g(r) values were close to zero. As the distance increased, the g(r) value also rose to the first and second peaks. According to the plot, the maximum RDF values occurred for r = 0.52 nm and r = 0.94 nm which is an indication of a tight interaction between Berberine and the oil/surfactant groups. Fig. 15B is a snapshot of one of the aggregates in the last nanosecond of the simulation. The photo indicates that amphiphilic properties of the molecules were the main reason for the formation of the self-assemblies. In each aggregate, the oil groups (in grey) were surrounded by the long tails of Tween 80 or Span 60 (in blue) molecules and the Berberine molecules (in yellow) were placed on the surface of the spheroid aggregates. sections.heading: 4. Conclusion
sections.text:
This paper describes the preparation of Nano-Ber using the oil-in-water (O/W) emulsion technique with the aim to improve the oral bioavailability and solubility in water of Berberine. The optimized formulation was obtained with olive oil that was used as a suitable oil phase, Tween 80 and Span 60 as surfactant and co-surfactant, respectively, with a fixed ratio of 1:2:2 (oil:surfactant:co-surfactant). DLS, TEM, FESEM,
and AFM results indicated that the mean particle size of Nano-Ber was 43.7  3.6 nm with a spherical
shape, uniform distribution and stability for about five months. According to antioxidant activities, NanoBer has a higher potential than Berberine and can be utilized in delivering health beneficial effects through therapeutic applications and functional food. Moreover, a cytotoxicity assay suggests that Nano-Ber has the potential to become a treatment strategy for fatty liver in the future. Meanwhile, the interaction between Nano-Ber with HSA and HTF was investigated by fluorescence, UV absorption, and CD spectroscopies. The results indicated that the fluorescence quenching mechanisms for HSA and HTF through Nano-Ber binding were likely static. Thermodynamic parameters of HSA-Nano-Ber and HTFNano-Ber complexes show that hydrogen bonds and van der Walls forces play essential roles in the complex formation. Binding distances of 1.82 nm and 2.16 nm were estimated, suggesting a high probability of the HSA-Nano-Ber and HTF-Nano-Ber energy transfer.
This work provides valuable information regarding the transportation and distribution of Nano-Ber in vivo, which interprets the biochemical and biophysical data already accumulated during drug interactions with the protein. On the other hand, in this study, we also tried to understand the mechanisms involved in the formation of the nano-emulsion. For this purpose, we took advantage of MD simulation studies, throughout which the oil components of the system were placed in the core of the nano-droplets and surfactants covered the hydrophobic groups of the oils. Finally, Berberine molecules were positioned on the surface of nano-aggregates with electrostatic interactions. This process occurred spontaneously, and short-range interactions not involving bonds played the main role in this event.

metadata.abstractText: Berberine is widely used in traditional Iranian medicine to treat diabetes and inflammatory conditions and also as an anticancer and hepato-protective agent. This study was aimed at developing a method for the preparation of Berberine nanoparticles (Nano-Ber) in order to improve its aqueous-phase solubility and its complex formation with human serum albumin (HSA) and holo-transferrin (HTF) from the viewpoint of interaction behavior. Nano-Ber was prepared with olive oil as the oil phase, Tween 80 as the surfactant, and Span 60 as the co-surfactant. Nano-Ber was obtained with a spherical shape and a mean particle size of 43.7  3.6 nm, with an optimal oil:surfactant:co-surfactant ratio of 1:2:2, w/w/w. The antioxidant activity of Nano-Ber in comparison with Berberine was tested using DPPH and it was found that Nano-Ber had a large antioxidant activity. The cytotoxicity effects of Nano-Ber and Berberine on HepG2 were compared by MTT assay and detected in the treated (human liver cancer cell line) HepG2 cells at concentrations up to 0.1 mM. The binding constants of HSA-Nano-Ber and HTF-Nano-Ber complexes formation were (2.93  0.02) × 10 4 M -1 and (9.62  0.03) × 10 3 M -1 respectively. Hydrogen bonds and van der Waals interactions were the predominant forces in the HSA-Nano-Ber and HTF-Nano-Ber complexes, and the process of Nano-Ber binding HSA and HTF was driven by H 0 = -122.76 kJ.mol -1 , S 0 = -325.49 J.mol -1 K -1 for HSA and H 0 = -125.09 kJ.mol -1 , S 0 = -343.37 J.mol -1 K -1 for HTF. The results of the simulation demonstrated that the Nano-Ber molecules were stabilized on the surface of final aggregates through both hydrophilic and hydrophobic interactions.
